description.p: The spfe element is the root element of a SPFE configuration file.

You can spread your configuration over multiple configuration files. Each file must have a spfe root element. The spfe command requires a spfe configuration file as a parameter. This is the configuration file that defines the properties for an individual build. It may include more general property files that are shared by multiple builds. You include other spfe configuration files using the /spfe/include element.

The include element is used to include other SPFE configuraiton files in the current configuration file. Depending on the include behavior for each element, the elements in the current file will either be added to the elements in the included file or will replace the elements in the included file. See the Include Behavior section of each entry in this reference to see how each element is handled.

include-behavior.p: When an included file is read, any includes in that file are read as well. Be careful not to create circular includes.

description.p: The URL of the file to load. Note that XML Catalogs are not use to resolve this URL. To ensure portability of your configuration file, either use a relative URL or use /spfe/define to create a constant for the root of the file path.
The define element is used to define string constants that can be used to define other properites.

To use a defined value in setting another property you surround the property name with ${ and }, as in the use of the HOME constant in the example above. The variables HOME (the user's home directory) and SPFEOT_HOME (the location of the SPFE Open Toolkit) are predefined. (HOME is taken from the operating system, and SPFTOT_HOME must be set as an environment variable when you install the SPFE Open Toolkit).

include-behavior.p: Definitions from included files are added to the definitions in the current file and the combined set of definitions is used in expanding constants in the property definitions in all files. (In other words, there it makes no difference where a particular constant is defined.)
A definition in the current file with the same name as a definition in an included file overrides the definition from an included file.

description.p: The name of the constant you are defining. The name must conform to the XML NCName type. In practice, for visibility, it should consist of upper case letters and underscores, with no spaces.

The value of the constant. This can be anything you like, and you may include other constants in the value of the constant you are defining, as long as you do not create a circular definition. The value will be substituted for the constant wherever it occurs as a straight string substitution.

The topic-set-id element specifies the identifier for the current topic set. This identifier can be used to create a reference to the topic set. It is also used to create file and directory names, so it should be a value that is a valid file name (minus extension) on all target systems.

description.p: The publication-info element is a wrapper for the settings that define the publication information for a topic set.

include-behavior.p: The sub-elements in the current file individually take precedence over the same subelement in an included file. This means that you cannot override the entire publication-info element in the current file, only the individual sub files. This behavior is useful, for example, in situations where a sub-product has a different release number from other products in a documentation set. Shared publication information, including the release number, can be set in a shared file, and then overriden for products with a different release number.

description.p: A container element for a list of file selectors that select the link-catalog files to be used for linking topics. The setting becomes an ANT fileset expression in the build file.

The link catalogs for the current topic set will be created in the location specified by /spfe/build/link-catalog-directory. Make sure that the path specified by spfe/build/link-catalog-directory is included in those specified by /spfe/sources/link-catalogs.

You can also include link catalogs for other topic sets in the documentation set, or link catalogs from other documentation sets, in the list of link catalogs used to link the current topic set. The simplest way to have the entire documentation set use the same link catalogs is to set /spfe/sources/link-catalogs and spfe/build/link-catalog-directory to the same directory, and to define them both in the shared configuration file for the documentation set.

A container for the list of scripts to be used for each stage of the build process. Each build script for each stage should be written to use the standard SPFE interface for a script at that stage (which you can determine by examining the spfe.rules build rules file). Listing the full path of the script for each stage in this list will then cause that script to be called at the appropriate stage of the build process. If you need to change the interface to a script at a particular stage, you can override the build rule for that step by specifying a build rule with the same name as the one in spfe.rules. If you need to add additional steps, you can use the /spfe/scripts/other. If you do this, you must override the normal sequence in which the scripts are run in your local build rules file (the one specified by /spfe/build-rules.

You may specify more than one script for each stage. The build will create a temporary script file that includes each of the scripts listed for each stage. One, and only one, of the included scripts must have a template named "main", which the build rule will call as the initial template (unless you have overridden the build rule for this step in your custom build file.

This mechanism for building the final script by including a list of specified scripts allows you to customize the build for each topic set while maintianing a high degree of modularity and reuse in your script collections. A tyical way to use this mechanism would be to include a separate script at the presentation stage for each of the topic types included in the build. This mechanism does not prevent you from including one script file in another in the normal way, it just gives you a more flexible way of managing modular script files and assembling the right set for each topic set.

description.p: Container element for a list of link-catalog scripts. The link-catalog step is considered to be a sub step of the presentation process. In most cases, however, the link catalog build will be run separately from the full doc build. This is to allow you to build all the link catalogs for all the topic sets in the documenation set, so that topics can link to topics in other topic sets by reading the entire collection of link catalogs to resolve mentions.

A container for a list of image-list scripts. Unless you have introduced custom image handling into your system, the default image handling script should work for all topic types. The image-list script is part of the format step. It generate a list of all the graphics included in the presentation so that the build scripts can copy those graphics to the appropriate location in the output.

A container element for information on a documentation set. A documentation set is a collection of topic sets. To define a documentation set, you list the configuration files for each topic set in the documentation set using a /spfe/doc-set/topic-set element.

To build a full documentation set, you simply run the spfe build tool with a configuration file that contains a doc-set element directly (not via inclusion). The build tool will then run whichever build command you have specified on all the topic sets in the documentation set, as well as creating the files that belong to the documentation set as a whole.
